title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to the CNN Learning Modules
This website provides a gentle introduction to Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)
designed for students with no prior programming or machine learning experience.
All coding is done in the cloud using Google Colab ‚Äî no installation is required.

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Key Takeaways

Random Forest Advantages

Ensemble method combining multiple decision trees
Reduces overfitting through randomization
Provides reliable predictions with confidence scores
Shows which features are most important



Real-World Applications

Environmental Monitoring: Automated water quality assessment
Early Warning Systems: Detect pollution events quickly
Resource Management: Prioritize testing locations
Regulatory Compliance: Ensure standards are met

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Discussion Questions
Think about these with your classmates:

Accuracy: Why isn‚Äôt our AI 100% correct? Is that okay?
Importance: Why might dissolved oxygen be more important than temperature for predicting quality?
Real World: What challenges would we face using this for actual rivers or lakes?
Trust: Would you trust this AI to make decisions about water safety? Why or why not?
Improvement: How could we make the AI better? More data? Different measurements?
Ethics: Should AI make environmental decisions without human oversight?

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Summary
Today you used real machine learning - the same technology used by: - üîç Google (for search and recommendations) - üì∫ Netflix (for suggesting shows) - üè• Hospitals (for diagnosing diseases) - üåç Environmental agencies (for monitoring pollution)
You learned that AI: - Learns from examples (not programmed rules) - Can find patterns humans might miss - Gets better with more training data - Isn‚Äôt perfect, but is very helpful - Shows us what‚Äôs important (feature importance)
Most importantly: You did this all in your web browser! No special software, no downloads, no setup. That‚Äôs the power of modern technology! üöÄ

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Welcome to Machine Learning! ü§ñ
Today you‚Äôll use an actual AI model that predicts water quality. Once you run the setup above ‚¨ÜÔ∏è, the AI will be trained on 200 water samples and ready to make predictions!

What is Machine Learning?
Machine Learning is when computers learn from examples instead of following programmed rules. The AI you just prepared: 1. ‚úì Learned from 200 water samples (the training data) 2. ‚úì Found patterns about what makes water good or bad 3. ‚úì Is ready to predict quality of new water samples!

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Understanding Random Forest AI
What is a Random Forest?
Think of it like asking 100 experts for their opinion: - Each ‚Äúexpert‚Äù is a decision tree - Each tree looks at the water measurements differently - They all vote on the quality - The majority vote wins!
This is why it‚Äôs called a ‚Äúforest‚Äù - it‚Äôs a collection of decision trees working together.
Why is it good? - ‚úì More accurate than a single decision tree - ‚úì Doesn‚Äôt get fooled by unusual samples - ‚úì Can handle complex patterns - ‚úì Shows which measurements are most important

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Real-World Applications
Where could this technology be used?
üåä River Monitoring - Sensors measure water constantly - AI predicts quality every hour - Alerts sent if quality drops
üè≠ Factory Compliance - Check discharge water quality - Ensure regulations are met - Automatic reporting
üèä Beach Safety - Test swimming areas daily - Predict if beaches are safe - Protect public health
üåæ Agriculture - Monitor irrigation water - Optimize crop watering - Prevent contamination

title: Machine Learning for Water Quality Prediction
text:
Key Concepts You Now Understand
Training Data: The examples the AI learns from (our 160 samples)
Testing Data: New examples to check if learning worked (our 40 samples)
Features: The measurements we use to predict (pH, oxygen, turbidity, etc.)
Accuracy: How often the AI is correct (we got ~80-90%)
Feature Importance: Which measurements matter most for predictions
Confidence: How sure the AI is about its prediction (shown as percentages)

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
section: Option 1: Hidden Code with Toggle Button
text:
Option 1: Hidden Code with Toggle Button
Students can run the code without seeing it, but can click ‚ÄúShow Code‚Äù if they want to see it.

Show Code


import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Generate sample water quality data
ph_levels = np.random.normal(7.0, 0.5, 100)
print(f"Average pH: {np.mean(ph_levels):.2f}")
print(f"pH Range: {np.min(ph_levels):.2f} - {np.max(ph_levels):.2f}")

# Plot histogram
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 5))
plt.hist(ph_levels, bins=20, edgecolor='black', alpha=0.7)
plt.xlabel('pH Level')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.title('Distribution of Water pH Levels')
plt.axvline(7.0, color='red', linestyle='--', label='Neutral pH')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.show()

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
text:
Option 2: Completely Hidden Code (No Toggle)
Students just see the run button and output. Code is completely hidden.

import numpy as np

# Calculate water quality index
turbidity = np.random.uniform(1, 10)
dissolved_oxygen = np.random.uniform(5, 12)

wqi = (dissolved_oxygen * 0.6 + (10 - turbidity) * 0.4) * 10

print(f"Water Quality Index: {wqi:.1f}")
if wqi > 80:
    print("Status: Excellent")
elif wqi > 60:
    print("Status: Good")
elif wqi > 40:
    print("Status: Fair")
else:
    print("Status: Poor")

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
text:

Code is visible but de-emphasized. Still runnable.

import numpy as np

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
section: Option 4: Collapsed Code with Expand Option
text:
Option 4: Collapsed Code with Expand Option
Shows first line with ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù and expands on click.

Expand


import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Temperature data
temperatures = np.random.normal(20, 3, 50)
print(f"Average temperature: {np.mean(temperatures):.1f}¬∞C")

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.plot(temperatures, marker='o', linestyle='-', markersize=4)
plt.xlabel('Measurement')
plt.ylabel('Temperature (¬∞C)')
plt.title('Water Temperature Over Time')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
section: Recommended: Clean Version with Just Run Buttons
text:
Recommended: Clean Version with Just Run Buttons
This is probably what you want - descriptive text with run buttons, no visible code:

Analyze pH Levels
Click run to analyze the pH distribution:

import numpy as np
print("Analyzing pH levels...")
ph_data = np.random.normal(7.2, 0.4, 50)
print(f"Mean pH: {np.mean(ph_data):.2f}")
print(f"Standard deviation: {np.std(ph_data):.2f}")
print(f"Safe range (6.5-8.5): {'Yes' if 6.5 <= np.mean(ph_data) <= 8.5 else 'No'}")




Check Dissolved Oxygen
Click run to check oxygen levels:

import numpy as np
do_levels = np.random.uniform(7, 11, 30)
print(f"Dissolved Oxygen: {np.mean(do_levels):.2f} mg/L")
if np.mean(do_levels) >= 8:
    print("‚úì Healthy oxygen levels for aquatic life")
else:
    print("‚ö† Low oxygen levels - monitor closely")

title: Interactive Water Quality Analysis
text:

Students just see the run button and output. Code is completely hidden.

import numpy as np

turbidity = np.random.uniform(1, 10)
dissolved_oxygen = np.random.uniform(5, 12)

wqi = (dissolved_oxygen * 0.6 + (10 - turbidity) * 0.4) * 10

print(f"Water Quality Index: {wqi:.1f}")
if wqi > 80:
    print("Status: Excellent")
elif wqi > 60:
    print("Status: Good")
elif wqi > 40:
    print("Status: Fair")
else:
    print("Status: Poor")
